Molybdenum trioxide-decorated carbon nanotubes: An efficient and reusable catalyst for cross-dehydrogenative coupling-type aza-Henry reaction in aqueous media Gyu Yeong Go Robin Prakash Sirvin Rajan Sunwoo Lee ⁎ Hyun Chul Choi ⁎ Department of Chemistry, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 61186, Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry Chonnam National University Gwangju 61186 Republic of Korea Department of Chemistry, Chonnam National University, Gwangju 61186, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. Highly efficient and reusable heterogeneous molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) catalysts were prepared by anchoring MoO3 nanoparticles onto thiolated carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Transmission electron microscopy and X-ray diffraction analyses showed that the orthorhombic-structured MoO3 nanoparticles were successfully anchored onto the surface of the CNTs, and the average particle size was approximately 2.6 nm. We evaluated the applicability of the prepared catalyst in the cross-dehydrogenative coupling-type aza-Henry reaction of N-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline with nitromethane. The catalyst showed very good reactivity in water; the used catalyst could be readily recovered by simple filtration and reused eight times with almost unchanged activity. The high reactivity and good reusability can be attributed to the high surface area of the nanosized catalysts and the strong adhesion between MoO3 and thiolated CNTs. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Molybdenum trioxide Carbon nanotube Thiolation Heterogeneous catalysis CDC-type aza-Henry reaction Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. Introduction The development of efficient and green methods for the carbon–carbon bond-forming reaction is among the most important research areas in organic synthesis, because this process provides the fundamental carbon backbone of organic molecules. Although numerous reactions have been reported and widely employed for fabricating versatile organic materials [1,2], the search for more atom-economical, feasible, and green synthetic protocols is an on-going process. In this regard, cross-dehydrogenative coupling (CDC) reactions are attracting increasing attention for C−C bond-forming processes [3–5]. This technique enables direct coupling of two C−H bonds for generating new C−C bonds without requiring pre-functionalization steps for C−H bond activation, thus providing shorter synthetic sequences with high atom efficiency. Owing to the high dissociation energy of C−H bonds, CDC reactions are usually catalyzed by metal-based materials, non-metallic agents, or photocatalysts under oxidative conditions [6–10]. Despite remarkable advances, most of these catalysts still suffer from several drawbacks, such as harsh reaction conditions, poor recycling, and low regioselectivity. Therefore, the development of efficient and reusable catalyst operating under mild conditions remains an important challenge. Molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) is an n-type wide-bandgap semiconductor with various applications in electrochromic devices, electrodes of energy storage systems, and sensors [11,12]. Because of its good thermal stability, low cost, nontoxicity, and variable oxidation states, MoO3 is also used as catalyst in organic reactions and industrial processes, including alkane dehydrogenation, isomerization, and metathesis [13–16]. For the CDC reaction, Prabhu and coworkers first reported that MoO3 can catalyze the α-phosphonation of N-aryl tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives in organic solvents [17]. However, further studies on MoO3-catalyzed CDC reactions have rarely been reported, which motivated the present study. Herein, we report a new heterogeneous MoO3–carbon nanotube (MoO3–CNT) catalyst, consisting of MoO3 nanoparticles anchored onto a thiol-functionalized CNT substrate by a sol–gel method. From a practical viewpoint, heterogeneous catalysts provide numerous advantages, including low cost, reusability, and simple separation, compared to their homogeneous counterparts. In this regard, CNTs are very promising catalyst supports in heterogeneous catalysis due to their unique physical and chemical properties [18–22]. After characterizing the prepared sample, we investigated its catalytic performances in the CDC-type aza-Henry reaction, asymmetric nucleophilic addition of nitroalkanes, of various N-aryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives with nitromethane. This catalytic system showed good activities in aqueous solution and could be reused 10 times after simple drying. Experimental Reagents Molybdenum(V) chloride (MoCl5, 95 %), sodium hydrosulfide hydrate (NaSH⋅xH2O), sulfuric acid (H2SO4, ≥95 %), nitric acid (HNO3, 70 %), tetrahydrofuran (C4H8O, THF, ≥99 %), sodium borohydride (NaBH4, ≥98 %), t‑butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP, 70 wt% in H2O), and iodobenzene diacetate (PhI(OAc)2, 98 %) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. CNTs were supplied by Carbon Nano Tech. Co., Ltd. (South Korea). All other reagents were of analytical grade and used without purification. Deionized (DI) water was prepared using a Millipore Direct Q3 system. Preparation of thiolated CNTs Thiolated CNTs were prepared according to the procedures reported in our previous studies [22,23]. Typically, 2.0 g of CNTs was added into a 100 mL mixture of H2SO4 and HNO3 (volume ratio = 3:1) at 100 °C. After magnetic stirring for 3 h, the resulting suspension was filtered and dried under vacuum at 45 °C for 1 h. Then, 20 mg of acid-treated CNTs was dispersed in 70 mL of a mixed solution of 50 mL of THF and 20 mL of aqueous NaSH solution (0.5 mg/mL), in order to generate thiol groups on the CNT surfaces. The black solution was filtered, washed with DI water, and dried at 45 °C under vacuum for 1 h. Finally, the thiolated CNTs were obtained and used as carbon support. Preparation of MoO3–CNT catalyst The MoO3–CNT catalyst was prepared via the reduction of Mo5+ ions in the dispersed solution of thiolated CNTs [24,25]. In a typical procedure, 20 mg MoCl5 was dissolved in 20 mL of water under vigorous stirring, and 1 mL of 0.1 M NaBH4 aqueous solution was then added in one step. After stirring for 30 min, 20 mg of thiolated CNTs was mixed with the obtained reaction solution. The mixture was kept at 55 °C under magnetic stirring for 4 h. The resulting suspension was filtered and washed repeatedly with pure ethanol and DI water. Then, the final solid was heated to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min and kept at 300 °C for 3 h. Characterizations Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) profiles were obtained using a FEI Tecnai G2 F30S twin microscope operated at an acceleration voltage of 300 kV. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were measured with an X'Pert-PRO high-resolution X-ray diffractometer using Cu Kα (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation. Raman spectra were obtained at room temperature using a Renishaw 1000 micro-Raman spectrometer with a 633 nm He–Ne laser. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out with a Thermo Scientific K-alpha+ instrument using an Al Kα X-ray source (hv = 1486.7 eV). The actual metal content of the catalyst was determined by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) with an OPTIMA 4300 DV (Perkin Elmer). Prior to the measurement, the sample was treated with a mixture of HNO3, HF and HBO3 in order to dissolve it completely General CDC reaction procedure A mixture of 2-aryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline derivative (0.5 mmol), CH3NO2 (91.5 mg, 1.5 mmol), 10.0 mg MoO3–CNT, and water (1.5 mL) was added into a 5 mL glass vial equipped with a rubber septum and a magnetic stirring bar. The resulting solution was stirred under O2 atmosphere (balloon) at 60 °C for 12 h, and the process was monitored by TLC. After the reaction was complete, the mixture was extracted three times with ethyl acetate (2 mL). The combined solvent was evaporated, and the residue was purified by column chromatography on silica gel [using hexane/ethyl acetate (10:1) as eluent]. The used catalyst was recovered by simple filtration. After being washed and dried in air, the catalyst was reused in the next run without further purification. Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a) and 1(b) show typical TEM images of thiolated CNT and MoO3–CNT catalysts on the same scale, respectively. The thiolated CNT sample had a multiwalled structure with a very clean surface; highly crystalline graphitic sheets forming the CNT walls were aligned parallel to the tube axis. In the case of MoO3–CNT, the TEM image reveals that the CNTs were decorated with quasi-spherical nanoparticles with sizes in the 1–5 nm range and an average diameter of 2.6 nm (Fig. 1(c)). The nanoparticles were highly distributed over the surface of the CNTs, without local agglomeration. Moreover, no free nanoparticles were observed in the background of the TEM image. The corresponding EDS analysis reveals that MoO3–CNT was composed of only C, O, and Mo elements, without other impurity species (Fig. 1(d)). In order to observe the overall morphology of MoO3–CNT, the low magnification TEM image is also presented in Fig. 2 . The detailed morphology and structure of MoO3–CNT were further investigated by high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) and selected-area electron diffraction (SAED). The HRTEM image of MoO3–CNT in Fig. 3 (a) shows that the nanoparticles exhibited well-resolved lattice fringes with an interplanar spacing of 0.326 nm, consistent with the (021) plane of orthorhombic MoO3 [26,27]. The corresponding SAED pattern (Fig. 3(b)) displayed weak spots and a concentric ring pattern. The spots could be indexed to the (021), (110), and (111) planes of orthorhombic MoO3 [28], while the ring pattern was attributed to the (002) plane of graphitic sheets in CNTs [29]. These results indicate that the nucleation of nanoparticles took place on the surface of the CNTs, and the formed nuclei crystallized into orthorhombic MoO3. The phase composition and structural defects of MoO3–CNT were further analyzed by XRD and Raman spectroscopy. Fig. 4 (a) displays the powder XRD patterns of commercial MoO3 (orthorhombic structure, ≥99.5 %), thiolated CNT, and MoO3–CNT. The predominant phase of the nanoparticles in MoO3–CNT was orthorhombic MoO3 (JCPDS #05–0508), and no other crystalline phases were present [30]. Fig. 4(b) shows the Raman spectra of pristine CNTs, thiolated CNTs, and MoO3–CNT. The pristine CNTs displayed two characteristic peaks at ∼1340 and ∼1570 cm−1, corresponding to the defect-induced D band and graphitic carbon-associated G band [31,32]. During the decoration of CNTs with MoO3 nanoparticles, changes in the crystallinity of the CNTs could be estimated from the D/G band intensity ratio (I D/I G). The I D/I G ratios of pristine CNTs, thiolated CNTs, and MoO3–CNT were 1.20, 1.40, and 1.67, respectively. These results indicate that MoO3 nanoparticles with orthorhombic structure were successfully deposited on the surface of the CNTs. Although this resulted in the production of some defects and disorders, the tubular structure of the CNTs was essentially retained in the modification process. Fig. 5 (a) shows wide-scan XPS spectra of pristine CNTs, thiolated CNTs, commercial MoO3, and MoO3–CNT. The binding energies were referenced to the C 1s signal at 285.0 eV. As expected, C 1s, O 1s, Mo 2p, and Mo 3d signals were observed in the MoO3–CNT spectrum, whereas no other elements were detected. For the thiolated CNTs, the XPS spectrum displayed a S 2p signal due to sulfur-containing groups. However, the S 2p signal almost disappeared in the spectrum of MoO3–CNT. Since the XPS signal is obtained by collection of photoemitted electrons, this technique is very sensitive to the properties of the surface. For the MoO3–CNT catalyst, the photoemitted electrons from S atoms are screened by deposited MoO3 nanoparticles, which resulted in the featureless S 2p profile [33,34]. The atomic concentration of Mo, calculated from the peak area corrected by the sensitivity factor, was 3.60 at% (= 5.01 wt%). According to ICP experiments, the amount of Mo contained in the catalyst was 4.82 wt% (= 3.19 at%), which was consistent with that of the XPS result. Fig. 5(b) displays the Mo 3d XPS spectra of commercial MoO3 and MoO3–CNT. The spectrum of MoO3–CNT showed two peaks at 232.3 and 235.5 eV, which were assigned to Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2, respectively [35,36]. The observed peak position, splitting energy between the Mo 3d5/2 and Mo 3d3/2 signals (ΔE = 3.2 eV) [37,38], and symmetric features indicate that Mo predominantly as Mo6+ in the nanoparticles. These results further confirm that the MoO3 nanoparticles were preferentially anchored on the sulfur-containing groups. To evaluate the reactivity of the MoO3–CNT catalysts, we started our investigation by optimizing the reaction conditions using N-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline (1a) and nitromethane as standard substrates, and the results are summarized in Table 1 . To avoid the potential presence of transition metals originating from the synthesis of the starting material (1a) as catalysts, 1a was synthesized in transition metal-free conditions [39]. The detailed procedure and characterization is displayed in the supporting information. Organic oxidants such as TBHP, PhI(OAc)2, and H2O2 were used in a MeOH solvent system to evaluate the formation of the desired product 2a, which was obtained in 90 %, 81 %, and 59 % yields, respectively (entries 1–3). In contrast, oxygen, which is an environmentally friendly oxidant, did not produce the desired product under the same conditions (entry 4). Thus, various solvents were screened to identify a suitable medium for oxygen as the oxidant source (entries 4–9). Among them, H2O, which is a green medium, was identified as the best solvent in terms of reactivity (entry 9, 93 % yield). However, when the temperature was reduced to 25 °C, the yield decreased significantly to 15 % (entry 10). The activity of commercially available MoO3 and MoO2 was compared with that of the MoO3–CNT catalyst. Both MoO3 and MoO2 powders showed lower yields than MoO3–CNT (entries 11 and 12). We also evaluated other transition metal oxide catalysts (RuO2 and CuO), known to be effective in CDC-type aza-Henry reactions; these catalysts resulted in 2a yields of 92 % and 90 %, respectively (entries 13 and 14). As expected, the addition of thiolated CNTs without MoO3 did not afford any product (entry 15). Based on the screening results, it can be concluded that MoO3–CNT is an effective catalyst for the CDC-type aza-Henry reaction. Under these optimized conditions, we then investigated the reaction between various substituted N-aryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives and nitromethane in aqueous solution. After reactions, the residue was subjected to 1H NMR analysis (data is given in the supporting information). As shown in Scheme 1 , the methyl-substituted derivatives at the N-phenyl ring afforded 2b and 2c in 91 % and 92 % yields, respectively. Derivatives bearing tert‑butyl, phenyl, and methoxy substituents at the N-phenyl ring produced 2d, 2e, 2f, and 2 g in good yields. Derivatives with a halide species such as bromide, chloride, and fluoride at the N-phenyl ring also afforded the desired products 2 h, 2i, 2j, 2k, and 2l in good yields. N-(4-trifluoromethylphenyl)−1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline produced 2 m in 93 % yield. Additionally, N-aryl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives bearing dimethoxy substituents at the phenyl ring of tetrahydroisoquinoline were evaluated under the optimized conditions; 6,7-dimethoxy-2-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline produced the corresponding nitromethylated product 2n in 91 % yield, while 6,7-dimethoxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline derivatives with N-(4-bromophenyl) and N-(4-fluorophenyl) substituents reacted with CH3NO2 to produce the corresponding products 2o and 2p in 89 % and 88 % yields, respectively. To further assess the reusability of the present heterogenous catalyst, a series of recycling experiments were performed with 1a and CH3NO2. The reaction yield was monitored over the course of 10 catalytic runs, with the catalyst being reused up to 10 times. After each run, the catalyst was recovered by simple filtration and reused in the next run after being air-dried. As shown in Fig. 5, the prepared MoO3–CNT catalysts could be reused at least eight times with good yields (90–92 %), while a moderate loss of activity was observed after the 9th and 10th reuses (79 and 70 %, respectively). The high reactivity and good reusability of MoO3–CNT can be attributed to its high surface area, resulting from the small size and good dispersion of MoO3 nanoparticles on the thiolated CNTs. The strong adhesion with the CNTs also inhibits the aggregation of anchored MoO3 nanoparticles during the CDC reactions, which should also contribute to the reusability of the MoO3–CNT catalysts (Fig. 6 ). Finally, we compared the fresh and reused MoO3–CNTs in the catalytic tests by XRD and XPS techniques. As shown in Fig. 7 (a), XRD patterns of MoO3–CNTs before and after catalytic use are rather identical, indicating that there is no significant change in the crystallinity of MoO3 nanoparticles. Fig. 7(b) shows the Mo 3d XPS spectra of the fresh and reused catalysts. The XPS spectra of reused catalysts presented similar spectral features to the Mo 3d spectra of the fresh catalyst, indicating that the strongly bonded MoO3 catalysts remained on the surface of the CNTs. However, peak broadening was observed with increasing number of catalytic cycles. This indicates that the original Mo6+ species in MoO3 were partially reduced to the +5 or +4 oxidation states due to the generated oxygen vacancies [40,38,41], likely reducing the reactivity during recycling. Conclusions In this work, a novel catalyst is designed and prepared based on the immobilization of MoO3 nanoparticles on thiolated CNTs. The catalytic activity of the catalyst was determined against the CDC-type aza-Henry reaction between N-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline and nitromethane. This catalytic system also worked well with other quinoline derivatives to convert the corresponding products in good yields. Moreover, the catalyst could be reused 10 times after simple drying in aqueous solution. The good catalytic performance of the present materials can be attributed to their high surface area and strong adhesion between nanoparticles and carbon support. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first report demonstrating the catalytic performances of MoO3 nanoparticles for the CDC-type aza-Henry reaction in aqueous solution. The use of inexpensive MoO3 as catalyst makes the present protocol a more practical and useful synthetic route. The approach presented in this work provides an effective strategy for the future development of efficient heterogeneous catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Highly efficient and reusable heterogeneous molybdenum trioxide (MoO3) catalysts were prepared by anchoring MoO3 nanoparticles onto thiolated carbon nanotubes (CNTs). Transmission electron microscopy and X-ray diffraction analyses showed that the orthorhombic-structured MoO3 nanoparticles were successfully anchored onto the surface of the CNTs, and the average particle size was approximately 2.6 nm. We evaluated the applicability of the prepared catalyst in the cross-dehydrogenative coupling-type aza-Henry reaction of N-phenyl-1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline with nitromethane. The catalyst showed very good reactivity in water; the used catalyst could be readily recovered by simple filtration and reused eight times with almost unchanged activity. The high reactivity and good reusability can be attributed to the high surface area of the nanosized catalysts and the strong adhesion between MoO3 and thiolated CNTs.
coredata.dc:title: Molybdenum trioxide-decorated carbon nanotubes: An efficient and reusable catalyst for cross-dehydrogenative coupling-type aza-Henry reaction in aqueous media
